intro.title: Complete Statistics, Basu's Theorem, and Exponential Family
sec.complete.title: Complete Statistics
sec.complete.def1: For a family $\{P_\theta\}$ and a statistic $T=T(X)$, we say that $T$ is complete if, for every measurable function $g$,
sec.complete.def2: Equivalently, the only unbiased estimator of $0$ that is a function of $T$ is the trivial one.
sec.basu.title: Basu's Theorem
sec.basu.statement: If $T(X)$ is complete and sufficient for $\theta$ and $A(X)$ is ancillary (its distribution does not depend on $\theta$), then $T$ and $A$ are independent.
sec.basu.proof.title: Proof for Basu's Theorem
sec.basu.proof.label: Sketch:
sec.basu.proof.step1: Let $h$ be any bounded measurable function. Consider $g(T)=\mathbb{E}[h(A)\mid T]-\mathbb{E}[h(A)]$.
sec.basu.proof.step2: By sufficiency of $T$, $\mathbb{E}[h(A)\mid T]$ does not depend on $\theta$; by ancillarity of $A$, $\mathbb{E}[h(A)]$ does not depend on $\theta$ either.
sec.basu.proof.step3: Hence $\mathbb{E}_\theta[g(T)]=0$ for all $\theta$. By completeness of $T$, $g(T)=0$ a.s.
sec.basu.proof.step4: Thus $\mathbb{E}[h(A)\mid T]=\mathbb{E}[h(A)]$ a.s. for all $h$, which is equivalent to independence of $T$ and $A$.
sec.ex1.title: Example 1
sec.ex1.text1: In the normal model with known variance $\sigma^2$, the sample mean $\bar X$ is sufficient (and, in the one-parameter setting, complete) for $\mu$; the centered sample variance $S^2=\tfrac{1}{n-1}\sum_i (X_i-\bar X)^2$ is ancillary for $\mu$.
sec.ex1.text2: By Basu's theorem, $\bar X$ and $S^2$ are independent.
sec.expfam.title: Exponential Family
sec.expfam.bern.text: Bernoulli($p$) fits this form with $T(x)=x$, natural parameter $\eta=\log\tfrac{p}{1-p}$, and $h(x)\equiv 1$:
sec.expfam.bern.sum: For i.i.d. data, $\sum_i X_i$ is the associated sufficient statistic (and is complete in the regular one-parameter setting).
sec.expfam.ex.title: Example
sec.expfam.ex.text: In Poisson($\lambda$), $\sum_i X_i\sim\mathrm{Poi}(n\lambda)$ is the canonical sufficient statistic and is complete in the one-parameter family.
sec.num.title: Numerical Example of Sufficient Statistics
sec.num.desc: Simulate $100$ independent pairs from Bernoulli($p_0=0.1$); group outcomes by the sufficient statistic (pair sum).
sec.num.code1:
p0 <- 0.1
set.seed(1)
sample1 <- replicate(100, rbinom(2, 1, p0))
# counts of each pair pattern
colSums(rbind(
  both0 = apply(sample1, 2, function(x) all(x == c(0,0))),
  one10 = apply(sample1, 2, function(x) all(x == c(1,0))),
  one01 = apply(sample1, 2, function(x) all(x == c(0,1))),
  both1 = apply(sample1, 2, function(x) all(x == c(1,1)))
))
sec.num.note: The two single-one cases aggregate once grouped by the sufficient statistic (sum).
sec.num.cont.title: Numerical Example (cont.)
sec.num.cont.note: Outcomes with the same sufficient statistic value are treated identically by such rules.
